awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Superparamagnetic, antimicrobial nanocomposites and magnetic toothbrush for synergistic dental care
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to improve oral health.  Although the conventional antimicrobial compounds in oral cleaning products can kill certain types of bacteria, others are harder to remove. The proposed technology advances a new oral cleaning device that uses magnetic nanoparticles to address this challenge. This project advances the research needed to make this solution effective. 

The proposed project will develop a biofunctionalized magnetic nanoparticle ferropaste that can efficiently remove the oral bacterial biofilms under the control of an external magnetic field. The nanoparticles can significantly enhance antimicrobial activity. The core of the nanocomposites in this product have demonstrated strong magnetism and antibacterial characters in vitro. Under the external magnetic field provided by the magnetic toothbrush, the movement of the nanoparticles can be synchronized. Because of the nanoscale size, the nanoparticles can enter the oral biofilms through the pores on the surface and penetrate the cell wall of the bacteria. Therefore, these particles can disrupt the bacterial cell wall and break the dense biofilms to allow the released bacteria to be sufficiently eliminated by the antimicrobial compounds in the toothpaste. Additionally, the surface of the magnetic nanoparticles will be modified to increase the biocompatibility and favor incorporation into the biofilms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Executive Summary

The "Superparamagnetic, antimicrobial nanocomposites and magnetic toothbrush for synergistic dental care” project aimed to revolutionize oral care by creating an innovative nanoscale dental abrasive and antimicrobial that improves the effectiveness and safety of oral hygiene procedures. This product uses superparamagnetic nanoparticles which can be remotely controlled to scrub or guided to the affected area with an external magnetic field to be incorporated into a toothbrush device. Over the twelve-month project duration, significant progress was made in designing, synthesizing, and testing the product. This report highlights key project outcomes, impacts, and dissemination efforts.

Synthesis and Characterization

Engineered particles exhibited controlled composition, shape, and size distribution, ensuring optimal cleaning without damaging tooth enamel or delicate tissues. A novel synthesis approach was developed to produce the engineered abrasive particles using a green chemistry method. We also investigated several different synthesis methods and investigated the efficacy of particles in a range of sizes, phases, and with different coating materials. Characterization techniques, including electron microscopy, x-ray diffraction, magnetometry, dynamic light scattering, and zeta potential were used to confirm the particle's structural integrity, morphology, colloidal stability, and surface properties, validating their suitability for dental applications. 

Efficiency

The product exhibited efficacy in cell culture, including in multispecies biofilms and challenged 3D cultures. Nonclinical trials demonstrated that the nanoscale abrasive exhibited superior cleaning efficiency in a mouse model. The engineered particles effectively removed stains and plaque from tooth surfaces, resulting in improved oral hygiene outcomes. Treated animals exhibited baseline levels of markers for gum inflammation and infection. We did not observe significant toxicity to human gingival cell likes, or to the mice. The product also did not appear to cause or increase any inflammatory markers. At present, only a few specialized toothpaste ingredients, such as chlorhexidine and triclosan, are known to treat gum inflammation, whereas fluoride is primarily serves to reduce tooth decay.

I-Corps Participation

Under the NSF I-Corps program, the project fostered collaboration with dental care industry partners, facilitating the eventual integration of the product into commercially available oral care products. The engagement of industry experts ensured the translatability of research findings into practical solutions for consumers. Connections were made with dental professionals, manufacturers, distributors, dental product marketing professionals, and potential end users. The team performed an in-depth analysis of the market need and identified the ideal beachhead market. A key discovery was the cruciality of local sales teams and distributors in marketing dental products to professionals. The team has successfully produced a viable business canvass to streamline commercialization of the product.

Broader Impacts

This product has the potential to significantly improve oral healthcare outcomes by providing a more effective and enamel-friendly cleaning solution. Reduced enamel wear can contribute to a decrease in tooth sensitivity and enamel erosion-related dental issues. Restoration of demineralization once it occurs remains a challenge in the field of dentistry. Most currently available products are inadequate. Therefore, prevention is key. Additionally, simultaneous prevention of tooth decay and gingivitis is an exciting capability. Due to the complex architecture of the oral cavity, proper cleaning in cervices and below the gumline can be difficult. By pulling the active ingredient to the area of interest with an external magnet, previously unreachable areas of the mouth can be treated. Gingival bone loss caused by periodontal disease can often lead to tooth loss, a major cause of disability worldwide.

Dissemination of Information

The project team conducted educational outreach programs, including seminars and public talks, to raise awareness about the limitations of currently available oral hygiene products and the benefits of using the nanoscale dental abrasive. These issues are particularly pronounced in individuals undergoing orthodontic treatment and those with gum disease. The dissemination of information aimed to empower individuals to make informed decisions about their oral care routines.

The research was presented at the Lone Star Society of Toxicology Conference in December 2022 and at SPIE Photonics West in January 2023. The presenting author was awarded the Ocean Optics Young Investigator Award for her SPIE manuscript. We also currently have one manuscript under review, and another in preparation.

Future Directions

The success of this project has paved the way for continued research into advanced dental care solutions. Future investigations will explore additional applications of nanotechnology in oral healthcare, including species-specific antimicrobial agents, smart dental materials, and diagnostic tools. Further studies to facilitate commercialization of the product developed under this project include preclinical toxicology and human clinical trials.

Conclusion

The completion of this project marks a significant milestone in improving oral hygiene practices. MNT SmartSolutions has produced a promising solution that enhances tooth cleaning efficacy and treats gingivitis while also preserving enamel integrity. This innovation has the potential to transform the dental care landscape, leading to better oral health outcomes for individuals worldwide.

For more detailed information, please refer to the full project report and associated publications.

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2023
Modified by: Leisha M Martin
